clinical_study.brief_title: The Role of Ninjurin-1 During Systemic Inflammation
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective Study to Analyze Ninjurin-1 and Its Soluble Part During Systemic Inflammation

brief_summary.textblock:
- With the underlying study the investigators address the question if Ninjurin-1 (Ninj1) expression is altered in patients with systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) in comparison to healthy volunteers.
- The adhesion molecule Ninj1 is induced following nerve injury where it contributes to nerve generation. Besides it is described to facilitate leukocyte migration especially in the nervous system.
- The investigators hypothesize that Ninj1 expression is increased in SIRS patients, which will fortify its impact during inflammation and the transferability from bench to bedside.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective

secondary_outcome.description: routine inflammatory markers will be used to evaluate the grade of inflammation e.g. procalcitonin (PCT) Interleukin 6, lipopolysaccharide (LPS) binding protein (LBP). Retrospective evaluation for sepsis (bacterial infection)

other_outcome.description: Concentration will be measured in plasma samples as well as from whole blood culture incubated with 100 ng/ml lipopolysaccharide for 6, 16 and 24 h.

arm_group.description: SIRS patients no included in an interventional study no peroperative infection

biospec_descr.textblock: whole blood, plasma, RNA and cDNA extracted from whole blood samples

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- age > 18 years
- cardiac surgery patients
Exclusion Criteria:
- included in an interventional study
- Preoperative Infection (e.g. Endocarditis)
